Mustard Greens.name: Mustard Greens
Mustard Greens.hint: 6- 20 weeks, depending on variety and at which stage you want to harvest your crop - it's good to taste test.
Mustard Greens.harvest: Sow direct.  Eat whole yong plant when thinning seedlings.

Mizuna.name: Mizuna
Mizuna.hint: Harvest leaves as you need them - pick as you go.
Mizuna.harvest: Sow seed direct, and water well for continuous leaf production.

Florence Fennel.name: Florence Fennel
Florence Fennel.harvest: Blanching stems reduces bitterness. Cover the swollen stems with cardboard or paper after they start to swell larger than a golf ball.

Kale.name: Kale
Kale.harvest: Can be directly sown into prepared beds or established in trays and planted out as seedlings.

Spinach.name: Spinach
Spinach.hint: From about 5-6 weeks, as soon as the outer leaves are large enough.
Spinach.harvest: Grow spinach quickly to prevent bitter flavour, water well.

Endive.name: Endive
Endive.harvest: Sow seed in cell packs, as seedlings don't like their roots being disturbed, try blanching your endive to improve flavour.

Asparagus.name: Asparagus
Asparagus.hint: Harvest pods when about 3cm in length.
Asparagus.harvest: Plant sparingly as they are good producers. Harvest pods at about 3cm as they toughen quickly.

Squash.name: Squash
Squash.hint: Harvest when fruit changes colour at about, 10 weeks depending on variety
Squash.harvest: Look up some good squash recipes to use up any excess produce!

Amaranth.name: Amaranth
Amaranth.harvest: To make planting easier, mix tiny seeds with compost or sand before sowing.

Turnips.name: Turnips
Turnips.botanicalName: Brassicas campestris var. Rapa/ Brassica napob
Turnips.hint: 4-10 weeks, when root has developed into a desirable size
Turnips.harvest: Very easy to grow and quick to produce, you will need very little help to grow these veggies. Plant after a leaf crop, and be careful when transplanting. Space 15-20 cm apart.

Rockmelon or Cantaloupe.name: Rockmelon or Cantaloupe
Rockmelon or Cantaloupe.hint: In about 12 -14 weeks, the nearest tendril to the fruit will dry and turn hard then the stalk breaks easily away from the fruit.
Rockmelon or Cantaloupe.harvest: Fruit is ready when it pulls easily off the vine.

Cabbage (Tight headed).name: Cabbage (Tight-headed types)
Cabbage (Tight headed).harvest: Tight-headed cabbage includes plants such as Drumhead, Savoy, Wombok. Feed liquid nutrients at planting, then weekly. Mulch to keep moisture and warmth consistent. Cabbages can be harvested at any stage, and if cut deeply to remove primary head they can be encouraged to produce a secondary head. If a secondary head is not wanted, remove the whole plant before trimming

Sweet Potato.name: Sweet Potato
Sweet Potato.hint: 16-18 weeks dig up tubers as stems change colour. Only take what you need from the ground, as they will keep well while still growing. Tubers taken too early are still edible (if small)
Sweet Potato.harvest: A good place to start is by purchasing a sweet potato from the fruit store and planting it in a pot to start, or taking cuttings from the tuber. Sweet potato can also be grown as an aquatic vegetable, in fully submerged pots.

Carrot.name: Carrot
Carrot.harvest: Direct sow in rows, mix seed with some sand first to space plants out. Choose shorter varieties for heavy soils.

Jerusalem Artichoke.name: Jerusalem Artichoke
Jerusalem Artichoke.hint: Can be harvested carefully at any time while plant is growing and tubers are large enough, though a full crop will be ready in about 5 months.
Jerusalem Artichoke.harvest: Propagate by tuber- check for edible varieties. Can be planted from tubers bought at local markets or stores

Malabar Greens / Ceylon Spinach.name: Malabar Greens / Ceylon Spinach
Malabar Greens / Ceylon Spinach.hint: Start to pick leaves once plant reaches 50 cm
Malabar Greens / Ceylon Spinach.harvest: Grow directly from seed on a climbing frame.

Broad bean.name: Broad bean
Broad bean.hint: 14-16 weeks should see them start to produce
Broad bean.harvest: Sow seeds direct 5-10cm deep, 20cm apart. Stake or support with perimeter twine if exposed to wind.

Collards / Kale.name: Collards / Kale
Collards / Kale.hint: 50-60 days to maturity, pick leaves as required.
Collards / Kale.harvest: Sow seed in trays, then plant out in rows.

Lettuce.name: Lettuce
Lettuce.hint: Start picking leaves in a few weeks.
Lettuce.harvest: Direct sow seed. Require some shade in the heat. Pick and eat varieties are your best bet.

Silverbeet or Swiss Chard.name: Silverbeet or Swiss Chard
Silverbeet or Swiss Chard.hint: From 3-4 weeks harvest outer leaves as required.
Silverbeet or Swiss Chard.harvest: No garden should be without silverbeet, pinch out emerging flower buds, and keep moist to prevent 'bolting'

Eggplant (Aubergine).name: Eggplant (Aubergine)
Eggplant (Aubergine).hint: In about three months, pick before the skin dulls and fruit is still growing in size
Eggplant (Aubergine).harvest: Sow seed in punnets and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Plant monthly for continuous harvest.

Beans (Climbing and Bush).name: Beans (Climbing and Bush)
Beans (Climbing and Bush).hint: 2 - 3 weeks after flowering, shorter for dwarf beans. When beans snap instead of bend it's time to harvest.
Beans (Climbing and Bush).harvest: Plant a few seeds every three weeks for continuous supply.

Garlic.name: Garlic
Garlic.harvest: Plant cloves sourced from credible retailers.

Beetroot.name: Beetroot
Beetroot.hint: From about 8 - 10 weeks, but can be harvested before that if the root is deemed 'big enough'. Some varieties have been developed to provide a leaf crop also, leaves can be harvested as needed but don't take too many or the root will suffer.
Beetroot.harvest: Sow direct in ground. Soak seeds overnight before planting. Thin as required.

Asparagus Pea.name: Asparagus Pea
Asparagus Pea.hint: Harvest pods when about 3cm in length.
Asparagus Pea.harvest: Plant sparingly as they are good producers. Harvest pods at about 3cm as they toughen quickly.

Leek.name: Leek
Leek.harvest: Plant seedlings deeply and mound soil as they grow to encourage long white stems.

Cucumber.name: Cucumber
Cucumber.hint: Cut fruit from vine after 8 weeks
Cucumber.harvest: Can be unreliable during wet season

Chilli.name: Chilli
Chilli.harvest: Sow seed in punnets and plant out in 4-6 weeks.

Globe Artichoke.name: Globe Artichoke
Globe Artichoke.hint: 12-14 weeks, cut young flower buds with some stem attached. Cut buds when they are fully developed but the fleshy scales on the outside are still tightly wrapped up.
Globe Artichoke.harvest: Although these plants are very tough they will benefit from regular watering and feeding. Cynara is a herbaceous perennial so will produce for a few years before division is needed.

Cabbage (Loose headed).name: Cabbage (Loose-headed)
Cabbage (Loose headed).botanicalName: Brassica oleracea Acephala Group; Brassica rap
Cabbage (Loose headed).hint: Loose headed cabbage include pants such as; Tatsoi, Bok Choy, Chinese Cabbage, Choy Sum, Mizuna, Vitamin Greens. Feed liquid fertiliser weekly. Cabbages can be harvested at any stage, and if cut deeply to remove primary head they can be encouraged to produce a secondary head. If a secondary head is not wanted, remove the whole plant before trimming.
Cabbage (Loose headed).harvest: Mildew, damping off, aphids. Club root can be a problem when brassica crops aren't rotated.

Okra.name: Okra
Okra.hint: Harvest tender pods as they appear at about 8-10 weeks. Seeds from hardened pods can be used as a coffee substitute.
Okra.harvest: Plant sparingly from seed soaked overnight.

Parsley.name: Parsley
Parsley.hint: Can be harvested at any time, flavour will change when plants are in flower.

Watermelon.name: Watermelon
Watermelon.hint: 10-14 weeks, pick when tendril closest to the fruit is hard and dead. Leave for a day or two until it makes a hollow sound.
Watermelon.harvest: Lift developing fruit off the ground and protect from the sun.

Sunflower.name: Sunflower
Sunflower.hint: Leave flower heads on the plant to allow seeds to mature, when they are swollen and hard they will come away from the flower easily, you can cut the heads off dry well in the sun.
Sunflower.harvest: As well as producing seed, sunflowers can be used to shelter other plants that require shade in summer months. Grow in an area protected from wind.

Luffa.name: Luffa
Luffa.hint: Harvest fresh young fruits when they are 10-15 cm long, older fruit develop a bitter flavour.
Luffa.harvest: Use edible young shoots and leaves in stir fries.

Celeriac.name: Celeriac
Celeriac.harvest: Remove side shoots as plants grow, and water deeply to encourage better roots. Can be harvested early if need be.

Capsicum.name: Capsicum
Capsicum.harvest: Sow seed in punnets and plant out in 4-6 weeks.

Mangle Wurzel.name: Mangle Wurzel
Mangle Wurzel.hint: Leaves as required, and roots 15-18 weeks. Store them in the ground and continue to harvest the tasty leaves.
Mangle Wurzel.harvest: Water them consistently to prevent roots splitting.  Seed may produce multiple seedlings so thin to strongest plant.

Chicory.name: Chicory
Chicory.hint: Harvest leaves when the reach a mature size, can take as little as 3 weeks
Chicory.harvest: Plant seed in trays, and plant out in rows. Space 15 cm apart, pinch out flower heads as that appear.

Salsify.name: Salsify
Salsify.harvest: Remove spent flower heads to prevent this root vegetable spreading through the garden.

Celery.name: Celery
Celery.harvest: Plant in blocks to encourage longer stems.

Tomatoes.name: Tomatoes
Tomatoes.hint: Pick fruit all year as it starts to colour and ripen on a window sill to get it out of harms way. Cherry tomatoes will produce quickly and in abundance.
Tomatoes.harvest: Insert stakes before planting.  Lime soil and water consistently to prevent blossom end rot.  Pinch off laterals when  small. Plant  in pots if your soil contains bacterial wilt.

Coriander.name: Coriander
Coriander.hint: Can be harvested at any time after plant is over about 10 cm tall, harvest seeds from dry pods.
Coriander.harvest: Sow every few weeks to ensure supply, let some go to seed.

Rocket.name: Rocket
Rocket.hint: Begin to pick leaves as plants establish
Rocket.harvest: Fast growing and hardy but can be very bitter if underwatered.

Potato.name: Potato
Potato.hint: 12-16 weeks.  Dig carefully for small 'new' potatoes or wait until the green growth withers for full crop.
Potato.harvest: Use certified disease-free seed potatoes.  Plant in raised beds or well-drained soil. Mound soil about plant as they grow to encourage larger crops.

Shallots.name: Shallots
Shallots.harvest: Plant bulbs in the ground with tops just visible.  Or, sow seed in punnets and transplant.

Pumpkin.name: Pumpkin
Pumpkin.hint: 12 weeks plus, Pumpkins are ready to be picked when the tendril nearest the fruit goes hard and brown. Cut the pumpkin with plenty of stem, and cure them by exposing them to sunlight for a few days, this will ensure they keep well.
Pumpkin.harvest: Pollinate flowers by hand for reliable cropping by moving pollen from male to female flowers.  Female flowers will have a small pumpkin at the base. Do it early in the morning as the flowers open for best results.

Dill.name: Dill
Dill.hint: Begin harvest when plant is about 40cm high, pick as you need it. Harvest seeds from mature pods.
Dill.harvest: Sow every few weeks, goes to seed quickly.

Burdock.name: Burdock
Burdock.hint: Any time between 2 and four months. Or after the leaves have died back.
Burdock.harvest: Plant densely to encourage longer straighter roots at 10 to 20 cm apart depending on variety.

Radish.name: Radish
Radish.hint: Quick to crop, you should have these ready in about 3 to 6 weeks. Can be sown all year but fair better in the 'dry' season
Radish.harvest: Choose seasonal varieties, very quick to crop. Try a few varieties because flavour varies.

Huauzontle.name: Huauzontle
Huauzontle.hint: From 7 weeks you should be getting ready for harvest. Everything apart from the roots and stems is edible. Use this nutritious plant in place of spinach.
Huauzontle.harvest: Doesn't require any special care. The fine seed can be planted by mixing with a little soil before broadcasting over the bed then watering in.

Chives.name: Chives
Chives.hint: Wait 8-12 months to establish your clump, this will ensure great supply
Chives.harvest: Plant seedlings in clumps, use as a companion for tomatoes.

Peas.name: Peas
Peas.hint: About 10 weeks, the best way to check is to taste them off the vine.
Peas.harvest: Dwarf Peas require larger spacing due to their bushy nature. Space peas 40-80cm apart.

Parsnip.name: Parsnip
Parsnip.hint: Over 14 weeks. Generally Parsnips are harvested when foliage has died back, though they can be harvested at any stage. Harvest as you need them as they don't keep well - this may take some practice.
Parsnip.harvest: Plant directly into beds from seed only as seedlings do not transplant well. Prepare and loosen soil deeply as they are a long vegetable, this will help when it comes time to harvest. Soaking seed in warm water overnight will aid germination.

Long Yam.name: Long Yam
Long Yam.hint: Harvest from ground when the vine dies, give plenty of room to climb.
Long Yam.harvest: Propagate from tuber cuttings, root them in pots before planting out.

Choko.name: Choko
Choko.harvest: Propagate using the whole fruit. Wait for it to sprout, then plant. Vigorous grower.

Tumeric.name: Tumeric
Tumeric.hint: Allow your plants to establish a good reserve, and begin harvesting as needed in about two years.
Tumeric.harvest: Plant dormant rhizome divisions, ready for rains

Cauliflower.name: Cauliflower
Cauliflower.harvest: Sow seed in punnets, plant out in 4-6 weeks, taking care not to disturb roots. Sow regularly for continuous harvest.

Basil.name: Basil
Basil.hint: Continually as new growth is produced
Basil.harvest: Sow seed in punnets and plant out in 4-6 weeks.

Sweet Corn.name: Sweet Corn
Sweet Corn.hint: Check ears, about 2 weeks after flowering. You will notice the 'silk' shrivel and disappear, when ready the kernels will produce a milky substance when pierced. To remove from the plant twist the ears and pull down.
Sweet Corn.harvest: Grow corn in blocks to aid pollination and space about 30-40cm apart. When corn reaches about 40 cm plant climbing beans at the base. The beans will use the corn as a climbing frame! Shake the corn gently while flowering to release the pollen from the male flower onto the 'silk' which is the female flower. This will ensure a great yield.

Oregano.name: Oregano
Oregano.hint: Harvest and dry or use fresh oregano after your plant sprawls out to more than 20 cm.
Oregano.harvest: A good companion plant that will flower readily to attract pollinating insects.

Pak Bok, Tatsoi, Bok Choy, Wong Bok.name: Pak Bok, Tatsoi, Bok Choy, Wong Bok
Pak Bok, Tatsoi, Bok Choy, Wong Bok.hint: These plants can be harvested at any stage of their life and eaten. Specific harvest times will vary from variety, and time of year.
Pak Bok, Tatsoi, Bok Choy, Wong Bok.harvest: Keep plants growing quickly to prevent stress and bolting to seed.  If plants start to form flowers, harvest immediately.  Sow crops every 4 weeks for continual supply.  Depending on variety, thin to between 10-30cm.

Water Chestnut.name: Water Chestnut
Water Chestnut.harvest: Plant in wet soil or in a tub full of water, with well composted soil. Planting material only available at specific times.

Zucchini.name: Zucchini
Zucchini.hint: Start harvesting in as little as 6 weeks
Zucchini.harvest: Sow seed in punnets, plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow regularly for continuous harvest.

Spring Onions.name: Spring Onions
Spring Onions.hint: Anytime after they reach about 15-20 cm high.
Spring Onions.harvest: Sow seed into trays and plant out when at seedling stage. Spring onions are available in punnets also. Plant with carrots as the two make excellent companions and bring out the best in each other.

Rosella.name: Rosella
Rosella.hint: 6 weeks foliage can be harvested, harvest Flower calyx when mature and plump at about 5-6 months.
Rosella.harvest: Grow from seed, can be propagated by cuttings but yield can suffer from this method. Grow in the sun.

Peanuts.name: Peanuts
Peanuts.hint: About 4 months -January 'Nuts' are below the surface! seive soil to collect the whole bounty, dry immediately. Turn green matter back into the soil to compost
Peanuts.harvest: Plant from seed - look to plant 'raw peanuts'

Onion.name: Onion
Onion.harvest: Be patient with seeds as they can take up to three weeks. Space out seedlings well to 10 - 15 cm in rows 30 cm apart.

Arrowhead.name: Arrowhead
Arrowhead.harvest: Aquatic plant, grow in a bath tub in rich soil.

Broccoli.name: Broccoli
Broccoli.harvest: Sow seed in punnets, plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow regularly for continuous harvest.

Ginger.name: Ginger
Ginger.hint: Don't harvest for the first year (or even better, second) so your plant can establish a good resource, harvest as needed
Ginger.harvest: Propagate from rhizome divisions and plant in a shady area. Plant in a few places to ensure you have a good supply.

Vietnamese Mint.name: Vietnamese Mint
Vietnamese Mint.harvest: Propagate via cutting, or purchase in pots. Can be grown in water pots or boggy sections of the garden.

Quinoa (pronounced kin-wa).name: Quinoa (pronounced kin-wa)
Quinoa (pronounced kin-wa).hint: When leaves have dropped and seeds are dried and hard
Quinoa (pronounced kin-wa).harvest: Foliage can be used as a substitute for spinach and is very nutritious. Seeds must be washed to remove a bitter waxy substance called a 'Saponin' - this is the plant's natural defence against predators. Wash seeds until water is clear and free of froth. When cooked you will notice the seed has germinated. Great substitute for cous cous.

Warrigal Greens, New Zealand Spinach, Bo.name: Warrigal Greens, New Zealand Spinach, Botany Bay Spinach
Warrigal Greens, New Zealand Spinach, Bo.harvest: Grow in frost-free climates. Can be grown from seed, cuttings or self-layered sections.

Taro.name: Taro
Taro.hint: Harvest when the plant dies back, about 6-7 months after planting.
Taro.harvest: Propagate via cuttings- check for edible varieties
